elements.content: Li­(I) and Na­(I) complexes of the fluorescent dye syn-(Me,Me)­bimane were isolated and crystallographically characterized, revealing the bimane as a principal component in diverse coordination topologies, including discrete and polymeric structures. The bimane exhibits multiple functions in these frameworks, acting as a variable-denticity O-donor ligand, π-stacking unit, and hydrogen bond acceptor. These features highlight a new role for syn-bimanes, not as fluorophores, but as versatile building blocks in metal coordination architectures.

elements.content: The fluorescent dye syn-(Me,Me)­bimane was mixed with Li­(I) and Na­(I) salts, yielding a diverse assortment of discrete complexes and coordination polymers, where the bimane functions as a variable-denticity O-donor ligand, π-stacking unit, and hydrogen bond acceptor. These features highlight a new role for syn-bimanes, not as fluorophores, but as versatile building blocks in metal coordination architectures.

elements.content:
Published as part of the Crystal Growth and Design Israel Goldberg Memorial virtual special issue

Introduction

syn-Bimanes are hetero-bicyclic compounds that share a common core structure, 1,5-diazabicyclo[3.3.0]­octa-2,7-diene-4,6-dione (), and are primarily employed as fluorescent labels for biomolecules, such as peptides and nucleic acids. These compounds were introduced in the late 1970s by Kosower and co-workers, who developed their syntheses, studied their spectroscopic properties, and demonstrated their application to biological systems. The molecular structures of the bimanes were elucidated in collaboration with Goldberg and co-workers, who crystallographically examined numerous members of the bimane family.

Published as part of the Crystal Growth and Design Israel Goldberg Memorial virtual special issue 

Introduction

These compounds were introduced in the late 1970s by Kosower and co-workers, who developed their syntheses, studied their spectroscopic properties, and demonstrated their application to biological systems. The molecular structures of the bimanes were elucidated in collaboration with Goldberg and co-workers, who crystallographically examined numerous members of the bimane family.

elements.content: The use of syn-bimanes as fluorescent dyes is often made in biological media, which typically contain substantial concentrations of metal cations, such as alkali and alkaline-earth ions. At the same time, the syn-bimane scaffold exhibits features that are characteristic of metal-binding ligands, most prominent of which being an imide moiety with two coplanar parallel carbonyl groups that appear predisposed for metal chelation. Nevertheless, despite being known and used for 40 years, the coordination chemistry of syn-bimanes, and its spectroscopic implications, have not been previously explored. This prompted us to embark on a focused investigation of syn-bimane complexation by various metal centers, utilizing the strongly fluorescent syn-(Me,Me)­bimane (1; ) as a representative of the syn-bimane family.

elements.content: Recently, we reported the first example of a metal-coordinated bimane, in the form of a cationic Pd­(II) complex containing 1 as a ligand, [Pd­(PPh3)2(1)]­(BF4)2 (complex 2; ). Subsequently, we studied the interactions of 1 with the salt NaBPh4, demonstrating that the biorelevant Na­(I) ion induces the quenching of bimane fluorescence in solution, and isolating three well-defined Na-bimane complexes, namely, [Na­(1)2]­BPh4, [Na2(1)4(CH3CN)2]­(BPh4)2, and [Na2(1)6]­(BPh4)2 (complexes 3, 4, and 5, respectively; ). In all of these complexes, the bimane appeared as a bidentate chelating ligand (κ2O,O′), but in the Na­(I) complexes it also exhibited other coordination modes, namely, O,O′-chelating-cum-O-bridging (μ-1:2κ2O;2κO′) and monodentate (κO). All of these complexes displayed discrete cationic structures, mostly featuring outer-sphere anions, with the exception of 3, wherein the BPh4 – counterion appears to partake in Na+–π interactions and phenyl-bimane π–π stacking.
elements.clean_text: Recently, we reported the first example of a metal-coordinated bimane, in the form of a cationic Pd(II) complex containing 1 as a ligand, [Pd(PPh3)2(1)](BF4)2 (complex 2; ). Subsequently, we studied the interactions of 1 with the salt NaBPh4, demonstrating that the biorelevant Na(I) ion induces the quenching of bimane fluorescence in solution, and isolating three well-defined Na-bimane complexes, namely, [Na(1)2]BPh4, [Na2(1)4(CH3CN)2](BPh4)2, and [Na2(1)6](BPh4)2 (complexes 3, 4, and 5, respectively; ). In all of these complexes, the bimane appeared as a bidentate chelating ligand (κ2O,O'), but in the Na(I) complexes it also exhibited other coordination modes, namely, O,O'-chelating-cum-O-bridging (μ-1:2κ2O;2κO') and monodentate (κO). All of these complexes displayed discrete cationic structures, mostly featuring outer-sphere anions, with the exception of 3, wherein the BPh4 - counterion appears to partake in Na+-π interactions and phenyl-bimane π-π stacking.

elements.content: Crystal structures of the previously reported complexes of 1 with Pd­(II) (2; excluding two BF4 – ions) and Na­(I) (3, 4, and 5; excluding BPh4 – ions in 4 and 5). elements.content: As part of our efforts to deepen our understanding of the coordination chemistry of bimanes, we undertook an X-ray crystallographic study of new complexes of 1 with Li­(I) and Na­(I), employing several salts of these metals with various monoanions (see below). This investigation revealed the bimane to be involved in a wealth of coordination topologies, including both discrete and polymeric structures, and to contribute to these structures as a variable-denticity O-donor ligand, a π-stacking unit, and a hydrogen bond acceptor. These results highlight a new role for syn-bimanes, not as fluorophores, but as versatile building blocks in metal coordination architectures.
elements.clean_text: As part of our efforts to deepen our understanding of the coordination chemistry of bimanes, we undertook an X-ray crystallographic study of new complexes of 1 with Li(I) and Na(I), employing several salts of these metals with various monoanions (see below). This investigation revealed the bimane to be involved in a wealth of coordination topologies, including both discrete and polymeric structures, and to contribute to these structures as a variable-denticity O-donor ligand, a π-stacking unit, and a hydrogen bond acceptor. These results highlight a new role for syn-bimanes, not as fluorophores, but as versatile building blocks in metal coordination architectures.

elements.content: The complexes described herein were obtained from 1 and an assortment of monoanionic salts of Li­(I) and Na­(I), namely, LiBF4, LiCl, LiClO4, LiI, LiOTf (Tf = SO2CF3), NaClO4, and NaOTf. Treating each of these salts with 2–3 equiv of 1 in acetonitrile, and then adding diethyl ether by slow vapor diffusion, allowed us to isolate crystals of a dozen new complexes, nine containing Li­(I) and three containing Na­(I) (see the for further details).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Isolation of the New Li(I) and Na(I) Complexes of syn-(Me,Me)Bimane

The complexes described herein were obtained from 1 and an assortment of monoanionic salts of Li(I) and Na(I), namely, LiBF4, LiCl, LiClO4, LiI, LiOTf (Tf = SO2CF3), NaClO4, and NaOTf. Treating each of these salts with 2-3 equiv of 1 in acetonitrile, and then adding diethyl ether by slow vapor diffusion, allowed us to isolate crystals of a dozen new complexes, nine containing Li(I) and three containing Na(I) (see the  for further details).

elements.content: As mentioned above, we previously showed that 1 can function as an O-donor ligand for both a transition metal, Pd­(II), and a main-group metal, Na­(I). In the former case (2), some covalency is expected in the Pd–O bonds, and this was supported by the observed elongation of the carbonyl CO bondsfrom 1.21 to 1.24 Å in the free and coordinated bimane, respectivelyas well as a decrease in the infrared stretching frequency of these bondsfrom 1737 to 1680 cm–1. These observed changes constitute commonly accepted signatures of metal-to-ligand backbonding. By contrast, Na-bimane bonding is expected to be an essentially electrostatic ion–dipole interaction, as suggested in previous publications addressing sodium complexes of electroneutral organic molecules. This was also evident in complexes 3–5, where only minor variations in CO bond lengths and stretching frequencies were observed upon bimane coordination.
elements.clean_text:
syn-(Me,Me)Bimane as a Ligand

As mentioned above, we previously showed that 1 can function as an O-donor ligand for both a transition metal, Pd(II), and a main-group metal, Na(I). In the former case (2), some covalency is expected in the Pd-O bonds, and this was supported by the observed elongation of the carbonyl CO bondsfrom 1.21 to 1.24 Å in the free and coordinated bimane, respectivelyas well as a decrease in the infrared stretching frequency of these bondsfrom 1737 to 1680 cm-1. These observed changes constitute commonly accepted signatures of metal-to-ligand backbonding. By contrast, Na-bimane bonding is expected to be an essentially electrostatic ion-dipole interaction, as suggested in previous publications addressing sodium complexes of electroneutral organic molecules. This was also evident in complexes 3-5, where only minor variations in CO bond lengths and stretching frequencies were observed upon bimane coordination.

elements.content: In the new lithium and sodium complexes described below, 1 exhibits all of the previously observed coordination modes, i.e., bidentate chelation, chelation-cum-bridging (μ-1:2κ2O;2κO′), and monodentate (κO), as well as a new binding mode, μ3-1:2κ2O;2:3κ2O′, spanning three metal centers (see below). Moreover, lithiation or sodiation of the carbonyl moieties in these systems does not appear to have any significant effect on CO bond lengths. The average lengths for coordinated carbonyls is 1.225(8) Å for the Li­(I) complexes, and 1.22(2) Å for the Na­(I) complexes, and these bond distances are comparable to noncoordinated carbonyls, e.g., 1.211(5)–1.215(5) Å for the pure syn-(Me,Me)­bimane. These data are consistent with metal–bimane interactions being mostly electrostatic, with negligible metal–ligand charge transfer, as previously concluded for complexes 3–5.

Moreover, lithiation or sodiation of the carbonyl moieties in these systems does not appear to have any significant effect on CO bond lengths. The average lengths for coordinated carbonyls is 1.225(8) Å for the Li(I) complexes, and 1.22(2) Å for the Na(I) complexes, and these bond distances are comparable to noncoordinated carbonyls, e.g., 1.211(5)-1.215(5) Å for the pure syn-(Me,Me)bimane. These data are consistent with metal-bimane interactions being mostly electrostatic, with negligible metal-ligand charge transfer, as previously concluded for complexes 3-5.

elements.content: In addition to its role as an O-donor ligand of varying denticity, 1 is also capable of hydrogen bonding. The same imide carbonyls that are responsible for metal coordination can also potentially function as H-bond acceptors. Moreover, the bimane may also participate in π–π interactions, by virtue of its extended π system, as already observed in complex 3, wherein short intermolecular contacts were found between the bicyclic bimane scaffold and the phenyl groups from the BPh4 – counterion. Lastly, the bimane core is made up of two planar pyrazolinone rings that are fused at their shared N–N bond, and this provides a semirigid framework, the flexibility of which is limited to a “butterfly” bending motion about the N–N axis. Combined together, the aforementioned features of 1its proclivity for metal coordination, H-bonding, and π-stacking, together with its relative rigidityrender this molecule a versatile building block for the construction of metal coordination materials. Its potential is certainly demonstrated by the rich assortment of structures displayed by its Li­(I) and Na­(I) complexes, which are described below.
elements.clean_text:
syn-(Me,Me)Bimane as a Structural Building Block

In addition to its role as an O-donor ligand of varying denticity, 1 is also capable of hydrogen bonding. The same imide carbonyls that are responsible for metal coordination can also potentially function as H-bond acceptors. Moreover, the bimane may also participate in π-π interactions, by virtue of its extended π system, as already observed in complex 3, wherein short intermolecular contacts were found between the bicyclic bimane scaffold and the phenyl groups from the BPh4 - counterion. Lastly, the bimane core is made up of two planar pyrazolinone rings that are fused at their shared N-N bond, and this provides a semirigid framework, the flexibility of which is limited to a "butterfly" bending motion about the N-N axis. Combined together, the aforementioned features of 1its proclivity for metal coordination, H-bonding, and π-stacking, together with its relative rigidityrender this molecule a versatile building block for the construction of metal coordination materials. Its potential is certainly demonstrated by the rich assortment of structures displayed by its Li(I) and Na(I) complexes, which are described below.

elements.content: Of the 12 metal-bimane species examined in the present work, five exhibited discrete structures, comprising cationic Li­(I)-bimane complexes with outer-sphere anions. The first of these discrete complexes is 6, [Li­(1)2(H2O)]­(H2O)­(ClO4) (), which was obtained by using LiClO4 as the metal precursor and crystallized in the triclinic P1̅ space group. It displays a distorted square pyramidal coordination geometry (τ5 = 0.05), as shown in a, with two bimane ligands occupying the equatorial positions, and an adventitious water molecule present in the axial position. The latter is H-bonded to an additional water molecule, which comprises the second coordination sphere and is itself H-bonded to the ClO4 – counterion.
elements.clean_text:
Discrete Li-Bimane Complexes

Of the 12 metal-bimane species examined in the present work, five exhibited discrete structures, comprising cationic Li(I)-bimane complexes with outer-sphere anions. The first of these discrete complexes is 6, [Li(1)2(H2O)](H2O)(ClO4) (), which was obtained by using LiClO4 as the metal precursor and crystallized in the triclinic P1̅ space group. It displays a distorted square pyramidal coordination geometry (τ5 = 0.05), as shown in a, with two bimane ligands occupying the equatorial positions, and an adventitious water molecule present in the axial position. The latter is H-bonded to an additional water molecule, which comprises the second coordination sphere and is itself H-bonded to the ClO4 - counterion.

elements.content: Both bimane ligands in 6 chelate the metal center in a bidentate fashion via their carbonyl oxygens (κ2O,O′) and are roughly coplanar. Each of the bimanes is slightly bent about the N–N bond axis, with interplanar angles (ϕinterplanar) of 166.8(1) and 171.3(1)° between the pyrazolinone rings. In the crystal lattice, the complexes are arranged in pairs, with the members of each pair being positioned back-to-back, such that one of the bimane ligands in one complex is π-stacked against a bimane ligand from the second complex. The crystal packing is shown in b.

elements.content: The remaining four discrete Li-bimane complexes were all obtained by using LiI as the metal precursor. However, all structures were found to contain the triiodide anion (I3 –) instead of the expected iodide, most probably due to spontaneous air-oxidation of the latter prior to crystallization. One of these structures is 7, [Li2(1)4]­(I3)2 (), which crystallized in the P1̅ space group. As depicted in a, it is a binuclear macrocycle of pseudo-D 2h symmetry, comprised of two tetrahedrally coordinated Li­(I) centers, a chelating bimane ligand on each metal cation, and two bridging bimanes that span the two cations (μ-bimane-1:2κ2O,O′). All bimanes coordinate Li­(I) through their carbonyl oxygen atoms. The linear I3 – counterions are confined between neighboring dicationic [(Li)2(1)4] fragments, as shown in b.
elements.clean_text: The remaining four discrete Li-bimane complexes were all obtained by using LiI as the metal precursor. However, all structures were found to contain the triiodide anion (I3 -) instead of the expected iodide, most probably due to spontaneous air-oxidation of the latter prior to crystallization. One of these structures is 7, [Li2(1)4](I3)2 (), which crystallized in the P1̅ space group. As depicted in a, it is a binuclear macrocycle of pseudo-D 2h  symmetry, comprised of two tetrahedrally coordinated Li(I) centers, a chelating bimane ligand on each metal cation, and two bridging bimanes that span the two cations (μ-bimane-1:2κ2O,O'). All bimanes coordinate Li(I) through their carbonyl oxygen atoms. The linear I3 - counterions are confined between neighboring dicationic [(Li)2(1)4] fragments, as shown in b.

elements.content: The bridging bimane ligands in 7 are only slightly bent, with ϕinterplanar = 172.6(1)°, whereas the chelating bimanes are practically planar, with ϕinterplanar = 179.3(1)°. Each pair of oppositely positioned bimanes is nearly coplanar, and the two planes defined by these pairs are perpendicular. Moreover, the 12-membered macrocycle circumscribed by the two lithium centers and two bridging bimanes is itself planar, with its constituent atoms displaying an RMS deviation of only 0.068 Å from the respective least-squares plane. It should be noted that although the bicyclic scaffolds of all bimane ligands in 7 are close to planarity, the thermal ellipsoids of their nitrogen atoms are all prolate, and this can be associated with bimane flapping motions even at 100 K, the low temperature at which the X-ray diffraction data were collected. The same can be said of many other bimane molecules in the various structures discussed herein.

elements.content: The [(Li)2(1)4]2+ units of 7 are slip-stacked in a head-to-tail fashion, thereby forming extended strands, as shown in b. In each of these strands, adjacent dicationic units are engaged in mutual π–π interactions involving only the bridging bimane ligands. Thus, a bridging bimane at the “tail” of a given [(Li)2(1)4]2+ fragment is cofacially π-stacked against a bridging bimane from the “head” of a neighboring dicationic unit.

elements.content: The three additional complexes obtained from mixtures of LiI and 1 were all found to cocrystallize with noncoordinated bimanes, as well as adventitious water molecules. Interestingly, they were all isolated from the same sample. Complex 8, [Li­(1)­(H2O)3]2­(I3)2(1)4 (), which crystallized in the monoclinic Pc space group, is the simplest of the three complexes, featuring a single bimane ligand coordinated to a [Li­(H2O)3]+ fragment in a monodentate fashion (κO), as depicted in a. Two such complexes are present in the asymmetric unit, accompanied by four unligated bimanes and two I3 – ions. In this system, a network of H-bonds is apparent, involving all bimane and water molecules (b). Thus, in each of the [Li­(1)­(H2O)3]+ complexes, the noncoordinated carbonyl is H-bonded to one of the water ligands, and all three coordinated water molecules are further H-bonded to the water ligands of a second [Li­(1)­(H2O)3]+ ion, as well as to neighboring noncoordinated bimanes.

Two such complexes are present in the asymmetric unit, accompanied by four unligated bimanes and two I3 - ions. elements.content: Both of the symmetry-independent complexes in the crystal structure of 8 exhibit slightly bent bimane ligands, with ϕinterplanar = 169.5(1)–174.1(1)°, while the noncoordinated bimanes range from bent [160.7(1)–161.9(1)°] to virtually planar [176.3(1)–177.8(1)°]. In addition, all of the bimanes in the unit cell are paired by antiparallel π-stacking. Thus, each of the lithium-bound bimanes is π-stacked against another complexed bimane that is symmetry-generated, whereas each of the noncoordinated bimanes is paired with another symmetry-independent unligated bimane. This π-stacking is not extended beyond the unit cell, but H-bonding does, mediated by the antiparallelly-π-stacked noncoordinated bimanes. All in all, the crystal lattice is composed of layers of LiI3-bimane-H2O clusters permeated by an expansive network of π-stacking and H-bonding, involving bimane and water molecules. This is representatively shown in c.

elements.content: Complexes 9 and 10, depicted in , are the last discrete metal-bimane complexes addressed here and were found together in the same crystal structure, belonging to the P1̅ space group. Complex 9, [Li­(1)2(H2O)]­(I3), displays a tetrahedrally coordinated Li­(I) ion surrounded by two bimane ligandsone chelating and the other monodentateand one aqua ligand, which is H-bonded to the free carbonyl group of the monodentate bimane. This complex is essentially a linkage isomer of 6, which could be obtained from the latter by simple dissociation of a carbonyl group of one of the chelating bimane ligands. Complex 10, [Li2(1)2­(H2O)4]­(I3)2, is a Ci -symmetric binuclear complex, comprised of two five-coordinate Li­(I) cations, two bimane ligands spanning both metal centers in an O,O′-chelating-cum-O-bridging coordination mode, and two water ligands on each lithium ion. The inversion center is located in the middle of the Li2O2 ring at the heart of this dimeric complex.

elements.content: The two complexes described above are accompanied in the unit cell by four unligated bimane molecules, which are intercalated between the complexes. With the exception of the chelating bimane of 9, all of the coordinated and noncoordinated bimanes assemble into two roughly parallel π-stacked columns, as shown in c. Interestingly, all of the π-stacked bimanes are bent, with ϕinterplanar = 149.5(1)–161.2(1)°, and all appear to be arranged in a shape-complementary manner, i.e., the concave side of one bimane faces the convex side of its neighbor. The chelating bimane of 9, which does not partake in π-stacking, is flatter, exhibiting a folding angle of 166.6(1)°.

elements.content: In addition to π–π interactions, all of the unligated bimanes also engage in H-bonding with the coordinated aqua ligands of 10. Complex 9, on its part, H-bonds through its own water ligand to complex 10 from an adjacent unit cell. Thus, the crystal lattice comprising 9 and 10 is made up of alternating layers of these complexes, with intervening noncoordinated bimanes, all interconnected by a web of bimane π-stacking and bimane-water H-bonding (c), in a manner reminiscent of 8. The triiodide ions are confined between columns of stacked bimanes from neighboring unit cells, as can be seen in c.

elements.content: Seven of the 12 metal-bimane complexes, isolated and crystallographically characterized as part of this work, were found to exhibit polymeric structures. These materials, based on both Li­(I) and Na­(I) salts, display diverse topologies, arising from different combinations of bimane and anion coordination modes, as well as bimane π-stacking. Six of the coordination polymers are anhydrous and solventless, containing only 1, the metal cation, and its respective anion. The seventh polymer also contains adventitious water as part of the polymeric backbone.
elements.clean_text:
Li- and Na-Bimane Coordination Polymers

Seven of the 12 metal-bimane complexes, isolated and crystallographically characterized as part of this work, were found to exhibit polymeric structures. These materials, based on both Li(I) and Na(I) salts, display diverse topologies, arising from different combinations of bimane and anion coordination modes, as well as bimane π-stacking. Six of the coordination polymers are anhydrous and solventless, containing only 1, the metal cation, and its respective anion. The seventh polymer also contains adventitious water as part of the polymeric backbone.

elements.content: Three complexesLiOTf-derived 11, LiBF4-derived 12, and NaOTf-derived 13display essentially the same type of architecture, as illustrated in , , and . They are all linear polymers, consisting of bimetallic units internally bridged by pairs of oppositely positioned roughly coplanar bimane ligands, and linked together into extended chains by bridging anions. The bicyclic scaffold of each bimane is tilted relative to the chain axisby 21–36°, depending on the complexsuch that the bimanes are arranged parallel to one another along the polymeric chain. However, because of the large bimane–bimane separations, there are no apparent π–π interactions between neighboring bimanes within the chains themselves. It should also be noted that the three complexes share very similar crystal symmetries, with 11 and 12 belonging to the monoclinic space group P21/c, whereas 13 belongs to the closely related P21/n.

elements.content: Their similarities notwithstanding, complexes 11, 12, and 13 differ from one another in the exact dispositions of the bimane and anion ligands, as well as in the coordination geometries of the metal centers. In complex 11, [Li2(1)2­(TfO)2] n (), the repeating unit comprises two tetrahedrally coordinated Li­(I) centers bridged by two nearly planar bimane ligands [ϕinterplanar = 176.4(1)°], each of which spans the metal cations in a μ-1:2κ2O,O′ fashion (a). Each of the triflate anions bridges one lithium center of a given monomer to a lithium center of an adjacent monomer, also in a μ-1:2κ2O,O′ manner. The polymer chain axis of 11 parallels the c axis of the crystallographic unit cell, and its repeating distance is about 9.9 Å. Even though π interactions are not apparent within the polymer chains of this complex, it does exhibit short contacts between bimane ligands from neighboring chains, strongly indicating interchain π-stacking throughout the crystal lattice (b). Layers of π-stacked chains are apparent in this lattice (c), with each layer comprising chains that grow in the same direction. Chains from two adjacent layers grow in opposite directions, being symmetry-related through a glide plane.

elements.content: Complex 12, [Li2(1)2(BF4)2] n (), displays a monomeric fragment comprising two Li­(I) ionsone tetrahedral, and the other octahedralspanned by two O,O′-chelating-cum-O-bridging bimanes, both of which are bent, with ϕinterplanar = 159.5(3)–163.6(3)° (a). One of the two BF4 – ions in each monomer is internally bridging, connecting the two lithium centers in a μ-1:2κ2F,F′ mode. The second BF4 – ion is also coordinated in the same mode, but externally, linking together adjacent binuclear monomers (b). As in 11, the chain axis of 12 runs parallel to the crystallographic c axis, and its repeating distance is roughly 7.1 Å. However, unlike 11, no interchain π-stacking is observed in the crystal lattice of 12 (c).

One of the two BF4 - ions in each monomer is internally bridging, connecting the two lithium centers in a μ-1:2κ2F,F' mode. The second BF4 - ion is also coordinated in the same mode, but externally, linking together adjacent binuclear monomers (b). As in 11, the chain axis of 12 runs parallel to the crystallographic c axis, and its repeating distance is roughly 7.1 Å. elements.content: The monomeric unit of complex 13, [Na4(1)4(TfO)4] n (), is a tetranuclear complex, which can be considered an adduct of two binuclear complexes reminiscent of 11 and 12 (a). All Na­(I) ions in this repeating unit are octahedrally coordinated, surrounded by slightly bent bimane ligands [ϕinterplanar = 162.9(2)–168.4(2)°], and triflate anions. The first two contiguous sodium cations are connected by a pair of bridging bimanes, whereas the remaining two cations are linked by a pair of O,O′-chelating-cum-O-bridging bimanes. Each of the triflate anions in the tetranuclear monomer bridges three consecutive Na­(I) centers, with two anions exhibiting a μ3-1:2κ2O;2:3κ2O′ binding mode, and two μ3-1:2κ2O;3κO′. Neighboring monomers are linked through their terminal triflate anions, forming coordination polymer chains that grow in the direction of the crystallographic a axis (b) and display a repeating distance of 12.5 Å. As in 12, the crystal lattice of 13 shows no interchain π-stacking (c).

Neighboring monomers are linked through their terminal triflate anions, forming coordination polymer chains that grow in the direction of the crystallographic a axis (b) and display a repeating distance of 12.5 Å. elements.content: The fourth coordination polymer identified in this work is the sodium complex 14 (), isolated from a solution containing 1 and NaClO4. This complex, which crystallized in the monoclinic space group P21, features a tetranuclear repeating unit, [Na4(1)4(ClO4)4] n , as depicted in a. At first sight, this species appears to be topologically analogous to the previous three polymers, with six- and seven-coordinate sodium cations bridged by pairs of oppositely positioned bent bimane ligands [ϕinterplanar = 161.4(4)–161.8(4)°] and pairs of ClO4 – ions roughly orthogonal to them. However, 14 differs from 11, 12, and 13 in two key aspects. First, each polymeric chain of 14 comprises two parallel rows of bimanes, each of which is roughly coplanar, as illustrated in b. In each row, the bimanes are aligned edge-to-edge, with small 0.3 Å gaps between them, and the two rows are longitudinally offset by about 5.5 Å, such that each bimane in a given row faces a gap in the neighboring row. Second, the monomers of 14 are linked together not only through the anions but also via the bimane ligands. In fact, each bimane in 14 simultaneously bridges three consecutive sodium centers in a μ3-1:2κ2O;2:3κ2O′ coordination mode. The same three Na­(I) ions are also bridged by a perchlorate anion (μ3-1:2κ2O;3κO′). Two such bridging anions are found per repeating unit and are accompanied by two nonbridging, chelating perchlorates (κ2O,O′). All of these structural fragments assemble into a linear polymeric chain that grows in parallel to the crystallographic b axis, with a repeating distance of 11.1 Å. It should be noted that although the two bimane rows comprising each chain are closely associated, as can be seen in b, they do not appear to engage in any mutual π-stacking. Moreover, no interchain π-stacking is observed in the crystal lattice of 14 (c).

elements.content: All coordination polymers mentioned thus far exhibit linear chains of paired, roughly coplanar bimanes, regardless of their exact topology. The three remaining complexes described below significantly diverge from this motif, displaying new architectural types. Complex 15 is a homoleptic sodium-bimane polymer of general formula {[Na4(1)6]­(I3)4} n (), which belongs to the P21/c space group. Interestingly, it was found serendipitously in a sample containing LiI, and its appearance is the result of a sodium-containing impurity. As shown in a, the monomeric unit of this complex comprises four collinear six-coordinate sodium cations, surrounded by two sets of three nearly planar bimane ligands [ϕinterplanar = 173.4(5)–179.9(5)°], each of which bridges three consecutive Na­(I) centers in a μ3-1:2κ2O;2:3κ2O′ mode. One such set of bimanes is internally bridging, whereas the second set links the monomer to the next monomer in the polymeric chain, which extends in the direction of the crystallographic c axis (b), with a repeating distance of 12.6 Å. Each set of three bimanes is arranged around the polysodium axis like a three-bladed paddlewheel, with roughly 120° between the blades, and two adjacent sets are staggered relative to one another (i.e., offset by ∼60°). When viewed along the c axis, it is apparent that each polymeric chain of 15 has pseudo-C 3 symmetry (c). The accompanying triiodide counterions, which are highly disordered, occupy interstices between the sodium-bimane chains, and are all outer-sphere, in contrast to the anions of the previous coordination polymers. It should also be noted that 15 exhibits no observable π-stacking.

elements.content: Complex 16 (), which was obtained from a mixture of 1 and LiCl, and crystallized in the monoclinic Cm space group, exhibits the simplest structure of all the coordination polymers described herein. Its repeating unit is [Li­(1)­Cl] n (a), comprising a single bimane ligand attached to a LiCl ion-pair via chelation of the tetrahedral Li­(I) center. Each chloride ion bridges two adjacent metal cations, thereby forming a linear polymeric chain of C s symmetry, wherein all Li, Cl, and N atoms occupy special positions on the mirror plane. The chain grows in parallel to the crystallographic c axis (b), exhibiting a repeating distance of only 3.9 Å, which is the shortest of all seven coordination polymers. In this system, the bimanes are significantly bent, with ϕinterplanar = 147.4(3), and are π-stacked front-to-back along the chain, each one being tilted by about 62° relative to the c axis. Throughout the crystal lattice, the polymeric chains run in parallel (c), with no apparent π-stacking between them.
elements.clean_text: Complex 16 (), which was obtained from a mixture of 1 and LiCl, and crystallized in the monoclinic Cm space group, exhibits the simplest structure of all the coordination polymers described herein. Its repeating unit is [Li(1)Cl] n  (a), comprising a single bimane ligand attached to a LiCl ion-pair via chelation of the tetrahedral Li(I) center. Each chloride ion bridges two adjacent metal cations, thereby forming a linear polymeric chain of C  s  symmetry, wherein all Li, Cl, and N atoms occupy special positions on the mirror plane. The chain grows in parallel to the crystallographic c axis (b), exhibiting a repeating distance of only 3.9 Å, which is the shortest of all seven coordination polymers. In this system, the bimanes are significantly bent, with ϕinterplanar = 147.4(3), and are π-stacked front-to-back along the chain, each one being tilted by about 62° relative to the c axis. Throughout the crystal lattice, the polymeric chains run in parallel (c), with no apparent π-stacking between them.

elements.content: The last extended-structure complex, LiBF4-derived 17 (), is also the most intricate. It has a net composition of {[Li2(H2O)4(1)4­(BF4)]­(1)4­(BF4)} n , but its exact structure varies along the polymeric chain, due to positional disorder of the lithium cations, as will be described below. This compound crystallized in the tetragonal I4̅ space group, and each of its polymeric chains runs parallel to the crystallographic c axis and revolves around a 4-fold rotoinversion axis. This symmetry axis is dotted with BF4 – ions, which are evenly separated from one another by 6.8 Å (a), and the boron atoms of which occupy special positions along the axis. Four symmetry-related columns of π-stacked bimanes are uniformly arranged around the same axis, and parallel to it, with the mean molecular plane of each bimane being roughly perpendicular to the axis (a,b). In each column, the bimanes alternate between two opposing orientations, namely, one in which the carbonyl oxygen atoms point toward the symmetry axis (inward-pointing), and one in which they point away from it (outward-pointing). All of the bimanes are bent, with ϕinterplanar = 150.4(3)–157.8(4)°, and exhibit positional disorder at their N atoms.

elements.content: Interspaced between the bimane columns and the rotoinversion axis, and located between each pair of consecutive BF4 – ions, are lithium-water clusters, each one comprising two Li­(I) cations and four H2O molecules. In such a cluster, the H2O molecules occupy four symmetry-related sites around the symmetry axis. The two Li­(I) ions reside in the interstices between these water molecules, with half-occupancy at each of the four possible positions, indicating that the placement of these cations varies randomly from cluster to cluster. This positional disorder implies that no single monomeric unit fully defines the polymeric structure of 17 and that it probably contains discontinuities, due to lithium vacancies along the chains.

In such a cluster, the H2O molecules occupy four symmetry-related sites around the symmetry axis. The two Li(I) ions reside in the interstices between these water molecules, with half-occupancy at each of the four possible positions, indicating that the placement of these cations varies randomly from cluster to cluster. This positional disorder implies that no single monomeric unit fully defines the polymeric structure of 17 and that it probably contains discontinuities, due to lithium vacancies along the chains.

elements.content: Regardless of their exact location within a given lithium-water cluster, each of the Li­(I) ions in 17 is tetrahedrally coordinated to two H2O molecules, one carbonyl group from an inward-pointing bimane, and one fluoride from a BF4 – ion. The latter anion serves as a bridge between lithium cations from two consecutive clusters, being coordinated in a μ-1:2κ2F,F′ mode, on average. The lithium-coordinated and noncoordinated H2O molecules partake in local H-bonding networks, which also involve carbonyl groups from inward-pointing bimanes, as well as BF4 – ions. The outward-pointing bimanes, which are intercalated between the inward-pointing ones, are not involved in any observable metal coordination or H-bonding. Finally, electroneutrality is maintained in the crystal lattice by the presence of additional BF4 – ions, which are noncoordinated, and located along 4-fold rotoinversion axes that are situated between the bimane columns of neighboring polymer chains (c).

elements.content: Since they were brought to light four decades ago by Kosower, Goldberg, and co-workers, syn-bimanes have been mainly used as fluorescent dyes for biological applications, but their coordination chemistry has been overlooked. We have recently begun to investigate this unexplored aspect of syn-bimanes, demonstrating that syn-(Me,Me)­bimane (1), a prototypical member of the bimane family, can function as an O-donor ligand for both Pd­(II) and Na­(I).
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Since they were brought to light four decades ago by Kosower, Goldberg, and co-workers, syn-bimanes have been mainly used as fluorescent dyes for biological applications, but their coordination chemistry has been overlooked. We have recently begun to investigate this unexplored aspect of syn-bimanes, demonstrating that syn-(Me,Me)bimane (1), a prototypical member of the bimane family, can function as an O-donor ligand for both Pd(II) and Na(I).

elements.content: In the present contribution, we significantly expand the portfolio of known metal-bimane complexes, introducing 12 new complexes of 1 with Li­(I) and Na­(I). Crystallographic analysis of these compounds revealed the bimane to be involved in a variety of coordination topologies, affording both discrete and polymeric structures, and assuming multiple structural roles, namely, variable-denticity O-donor ligation, π-stacking, and hydrogen bond acceptance. Taken together, these characteristics indicate that syn-(Me,Me)­bimane, and syn-bimanes in general, can function not merely as fluorescent labels, but also as versatile building blocks for the construction of metal coordination architectures. Moreover, the latter are expected to combine the structural and photophysical features of the syn-bimanes to afford new tailor-made fluorescent materials.

Moreover, the latter are expected to combine the structural and photophysical features of the syn-bimanes to afford new tailor-made fluorescent materials.

elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

General Procedures

Commercially available reagents were reagent grade or higher quality and were used without further purification. The organic solvents were HPLC grade and were dried over molecular sieves (3 or 4 Å) prior to their use. Crystal structures were analyzed using Mercury CSD 3.10.3, and Platon v. 90316 (for Apple Mac OS) and 91117 (for Microsoft Windows), and were drawn using CrystalMaker v. 10.3.3.

elements.content: To a solution comprising 40 mg (0.208 mmol) of 1 in 10 mL of acetonitrile was added 0.50 equiv (0.104 mmol) of the appropriate solid salt, i.e., LiBF4, LiCl, LiClO4, LiI, NaClO4, or NaOTf. The resulting mixture was stirred at room temperature for 1–3 h, after which it was placed under reduced pressure to remove the solvent, until it reached about a third of its initial volume. The product was then crystallized at room temperature by allowing diethyl ether vapors to slowly diffuse into the concentrated CH3CN solution. The crystals thus formed were kept in their original mother-liquor until isolation, immediately prior to collection of the X-ray diffraction data.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction data for 6, 11, 12, 13, 15, 16, and 17 were collected at 100 K on a Rigaku XtaLAB PRO dual source diffractometer, and processed with CrysAlisPRO. The diffraction data for 7, 8, 9, and 10 were collected at 100 K on a Bruker APEX-II Kappa CCD diffractometer and processed with SAINT. The data for 14 were obtained with the latter system, but at 296 K. For all complexes, except 13, data were collected using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54184 Å). Data for 13 were collected using Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å).
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Data Collection and Structure Refinement

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction data for 6, 11, 12, 13, 15, 16, and 17 were collected at 100 K on a Rigaku XtaLAB PRO dual source diffractometer, and processed with CrysAlisPRO. The diffraction data for 7, 8, 9, and 10 were collected at 100 K on a Bruker APEX-II Kappa CCD diffractometer and processed with SAINT. The data for 14 were obtained with the latter system, but at 296 K. For all complexes, except 13, data were collected using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54184 Å). Data for 13 were collected using Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å).

elements.content: The crystal structures were solved by direct methods using SHELXT. All non-hydrogen atoms were further refined by SHELXL with anisotropic displacement coefficients. Hydrogen atoms were assigned isotropic displacement coefficients, and their coordinates were allowed to ride on the respective carbon atoms. Crystallographic data and refinement parameters are summarized in Tables S1 and S2 (see the Supporting Information).

cln_elements.clean_text: 1  General Molecular Structure of a syn-Bimane (left; R1-4 = Organic or Inorganic Substituents) and the Representative syn-(Me,Me)Bimane (1; right) That Is Used in the Present Work

cln_elements.content: Crystal structures of the previously reported complexes of 1 with Pd­(II) (2; excluding two BF4 – ions) and Na­(I) (3, 4, and 5; excluding BPh4 – ions in 4 and 5). All atoms are represented by thermal ellipsoids at the 50% probability level. All H atoms were omitted for clarity, as were interstitial CHCl3 and H2O molecules in 2, and two interstitial CH3CN molecules in 4. Atoms are color-coded as follows: Pd, cyan; O, red; P, orange; C, gray; N, light blue; Na, magenta; B, peach.

cln_elements.content: Crystal structure of complex 6, [Li­(1)2(H2O)]­(H2O)­(ClO4) (a), and a representative segment of its crystal lattice (b; viewed along the a axis), showing the crystal packing. All atoms are depicted as 50%-probability thermal ellipsoids. H atoms were omitted for clarity, except for the H2O molecules in (a), wherein H atoms are shown as spheres. Dashed cyan lines represent H-bonds [shown only in (a)], and the blue quadrilateral in (b) marks the unit cell. Atoms are color-coded as follows: Li, magenta; O, red; C, gray; H, white; N, light blue; Cl, green.

cln_elements.content: Crystal structure of complex 7, [Li2(1)4]­(I3)2 (a), and a representative portion of its crystal lattice (b), showing the crystal packing, which involves π-stacking of bimanes from neighboring complexes.
